subject: Re: method testing?
msgSnippet: ... if ... work ... of ... Maybe you have in mind a more complicated case, but what would it take to *convince* you that your trimA method works? Does it
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "stclaus_imi" <cunsan@l...> wrote:
> hi,
>
> i have read many examples of using asserEquals(expected, theResult).
>
> mostly in those examples the expected is already determined. what
if
> i can't determine it first???? i want to test whether my methods
work
> for all possible inputs.
>
> say i have method : trimA(String s) that replaces all occurrences
of
> A/a with nothing. of course if the input is BaB the expected is BB,
> BaaaaB still the same. However, i couldn't specify all the possible
> outputs right?
>
> so how to do method testing?

Maybe you have in mind a more complicated case, but what would it
take to *convince* you that your trimA method works? Does it really
take every possible string? I'm thinking there is probably some
smaller set of cases that would provide 'reasonable' confidence.

However, you don't just have to use assertEquals.
What about an assertTrue (or assertFalse) based on 'A' or 'a'
existing in the string after the trimA() call?
What about counting the number of 'A' and 'a' instances BEFORE,
and making sure the trimmed string is that many characters LESS
in length?

And of course, if the input is ONLY A's and a's, do you get
a NULL or an empty string?

I think there are lots of things that can reasonably be tested
with only a few tests on a representative sample.

Richard.
